pr_title: Add syntax support for external function

timeline.message: Add syntax support for external function

timeline.bodyText: equals or compatible? For example return 0 will work for a double return type?
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: Hmm, good point. This is only changed because of the indentation so the logic already existed. Currently the behavior is that if the function return type is double, you have to return a double. So you have to say RETURN double'0'. I agree this is quite inconvenient. This provide the benefit that we can rely on the defined return type of the function to be the actual type and not worrying about having to insert cast though.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: I believe when I wrote the initial version, I check whether bodyType is coercible to returnType, but there were a comment to keep things simple for the first version. I think this could be nice feature to have, though not urgent.
replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: But if we have APIs to do it trivially why not - at least for implicit conversions where we don't need to cast?
replies.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: Ping
replies.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: This is not really a relevant change for this PR. I can submit a separate PR for this.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: ok
replies.author: kaikalur

timeline.bodyText: RoutineBody is a Node, not a Statement. See comments below.
timeline.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: Oops, I think I just renamed the previous Return to this and didn't pay attention -_-
replies.author: rongrong

timeline.bodyText: Return statement is a first-class citizen as defined in the SQL-spec. It is a SQL control statement similar to Call. I think we'll still need it in this PR. See comments below.
timeline.author: caithagoras

timeline.bodyText:
Either a return expression (SQL routine spec) or an externalBodyReference should be specified as a routine body, but not both. Although constructor has enforced this, this is where inheritance should be used (similar to what we're doing with other parts of the AST).
By doing so, AstVisitor will have methods visitRoutineSpecification and visitExternalBodyReference, and if/else shouldn't be needed in many places.
public class RoutineBody extends Node {}
public class RoutineSpecification extends RoutineBody  {}
public class ExternalBodyReference extends RoutineBody  {}

public class RoutineSpecification {
    private final Return return;  // Officially, this should be "private final ProcedureStatement statement;"
}
Simplification
Since we're (1) not supporting rights clause, (2) only support Return in SQL routine specification, (3) not using Return in other cases, I'm ok to simplify this a bit by temporarily avoiding RoutineSpecification, and just do
public class Return extends RoutineBody;
Although the structure I mentioned at the beginning is more locally correct and closer to SQL spec.
SQL-2016 reference
<routine body> ::=
<SQL routine spec>
| <external body reference>
| <polymorphic table function body>

<SQL routine spec>
[ <rights clause> ] <SQL routine body>

<SQL routine body> ::=
   <SQL procedure statement>
timeline.author: caithagoras

replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: Gonna take the simplified version. Don't see much benefit for adding so many classes when we are not planning to add those functionalities any time soon. 😛
replies.author: rongrong

timeline.bodyText:
As according to SQL-2016 11.60 9(i), pg. 1009
An <SQL-invoked routine> that specifies or implies LANGUAGE SQL is called an SQL routine;
an <SQL-invoked routine> that does not specify LANGUAGE SQL is called an external routine.

Let's add this additional check.
timeline.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: It only says that it's called an external routine, but I don't think it defines how external routine needs to be handled. I also didn't find anything specific about whether external routine requires a <external body reference>. So I'm not sure what to check here. Also the <language name> defined in SQL spec is very old. It doesn't have the languages we definitely want to support in the future like 'JAVA', 'PYTHON', 'PHP' or 'JAVASCRIPT' etc. Some of these could be defined inline potentially, so I don't want to rule that out.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText:
Those 2 lines of spec basically means:

LANGUAGE SQL <=> SQL Routine <=> must have SQL routine spec, cannot have external routine body.
LANGUAGE not SQL <=> external routine <=> must have external routine body, cannot have SQL routine spec.

Does those 2 checks make sense?
replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: That's not my understanding of the spec. And that's definitely not how other query engines that supports JS or LUA did it (they are not defined as external body reference). My understanding is literally, if the language is not SQL, is called external routine (which is a name that I didn't find any definition). I didn't find anything specify the relation ship between the name "external routine" and the spec <external body reference>. Would be great if you can point me to any documentation that made that association.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText:
11.60 Syntax Rules (1) pg. 1006:
An <SQL-invoked routine> specifies an SQL-invoked routine.
Let R be the SQL-invoked routine specified by <SQL-invoked routine>.

11.60 Syntax Rule (23)(a) pg. 1015
If R is an SQL routine, then:
a) <SQL routine spec> shall be specified.

11.60 Syntax Rule (24)(a) pg. 1015
24) If R is an external routine, then:
a) <SQL routine spec> shall not be specified.
replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: If you are specifically saying that if the language is not SQL there should be no RETURN xxx I think that makes sense (at least for now). I don't think anything that's not SQL should have a <external body reference> though, even though that's also true for now. Since SQL spec does not define languages like JS or PYTHON, we need to extend the spec to support this. I don't think they have to have an <external body reference>, though they could. We can choose to not go against SQL spec (not using RETURN definition) so that language SQL <=> RETURN expression holds.
replies.author: rongrong

timeline.bodyText: See comment in RoutineBody.java, separate visit method should be implemented and this if block would unnecessary.
timeline.author: caithagoras

timeline.bodyText:
We are allowing both identifier and string literal in the syntax, but we don't need to store them as is since we only care about the text. Instead, I think an Optional<String> name would be better, since the identifier/string literal are not used in an expression and hence no semantic difference.
See similar example in CallArgument.java and AstBuilder.visitNamedArgument
timeline.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: I kept them separate because otherwise we can't print out the original format in SqlFormatter.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText:
That's true, but do we need to keep the original format? For example

SqlFormatter renders array_sort(a) as "array_sort"(a),
Missing routine characteristics in Create Table are printed with default values.
So it does not look like we're promising syntactical equivalence with parsing + formatting.
replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: Sure, but what's wrong with keeping both? What's the downside?
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText:
Both have the same semantic meaning, so the remaining of the system don't care about whether the routine name was specified using StringLiteral or Identifier. This level of information should be encapsulated by the syntax layer and should be opaque to the users of the AST node. e.g. all that semantic analyzer, planner, execution cared about is "give me the optional name of external routine".


The class is not self-contained. From the caller perspective, there is nothing to guarantee that getIdentifier and getStringLiteral won't be both present. It requires additional checking at each caller. But again, this is less important than the first bullet point.


We don't name variables using their types - we give them descriptive names. In many places, we just call a StringLiteral value.
replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: Also, you just allowed Language to be an arbitrary identifier. If we follow the same logic of keeping both, don't we want to do that for language as well? So that we can differentiate SQL against "SQL"?
replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText:
We probably should keep both for language if we want to be strict. I can do that if you insist. The difference is the keyword SQL is basically a special identifier, which string literal is not.
I don't buy your argument. 1) String literals and identifiers have different semantic meaning. For this specific case it doesn't matter. But they are different semantic constructs. You can not change places where asking for one with the other. 2) The constructor already guarantees only one will be present. 3) Sure we can rename them.
If this really bothers you, I'm fine with only supporting string, or only supporting identifier.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: Yeah - this is a weird one. I can't think of any other place where this situation happens. I think there should be only one "child" of type Node  for the tree node. And you can have an accessor that can give the value of the string literal back.
replies.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: Changed this to only allow <identifier> for now. We will see whether there's a need to extend to StringLiteral in the future.
replies.author: rongrong

timeline.bodyText: Remove public for methods annotated with @VisibleForTesting.
timeline.author: caithagoras
caithagoras

timeline.bodyText: Using a static map would be easier?
timeline.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: I found this easier to read (code is at the same place). If code needs to be duplicated then I think a static map makes more sense. Currently I think this is fine. We have many this type of case statements in the codebase.
replies.author: rongrong

timeline.message: Add syntax support for external function
Add support for creating external function
Add support for creating external function
Add support for creating external function

timeline.bodyText:
We need test coverage for those cases, and also need to take a look at the spec what the expected behavior is:

CREATE FUNCTION ... LANGUAGE SQL EXTERNAL
CREATE FUNCTION ... LANGUAGE SQL EXTERNAL NAME
CREATE FUNCTION ... LANGUAGE JAVA RETURN 

https://github.com/prestodb/presto/pull/14219/files#r391879785 may have some useful references to the spec.
timeline.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: I think the first 2 are valid syntax.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: Sure, let's add the test cases then.
replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText:
I think the third one is also valid syntax though it might not be valid semantically. The order of validation should be:

whether the function namespace allows create
whether the function namespace supports the provided language
whether the provided language in specified function namespace support the given function body

Without checking the capability of the specific function namespace, all above mentioned are valid syntax.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: Sure, that all make sense to me. My ask is to add those test cases here so that we can see the query are passing as expected. If there are any behavior changes in the future, the test will catch that.
replies.author: caithagoras

timeline.bodyText:
I guess the reason we are adding those annotation is that we want to serialize the enum, but a Language can just be mapped to a JSON scalar, instead of a JSON map with always one single key.
We can do that using @JsonValue. There're plenty of examples. e.g. TransactionId.java.
timeline.author: caithagoras

timeline.bodyText:
This doesn't seems to be related to syntax support, and I suggest to move this to engine: CreateFunctionTask.
If I'm a community user and admins of some Presto clusters, I would prefer less configuration parameters to set and tune.
e.g. I want to use remote UDFs. I set up the UDF server, added the end points to the Presto engine config properties, and I already have function namespace manager setup from before. Why can't it "just work"? Can't the engine just figure out the support languages, like talking to the UDF server?
If engine and remote UDF server supports SQL, JAVA, JS, it is meaningless for me as an admin to configure the support language "python" anyway. So all I do here is mechanically set this configuration to match with whatever is available on the UDF server, because Presto requires me to?
Well, for the first step, if the engine cannot yet automatically determine what languages the UDF server support, can we have engine level configuration instead? If user truely wants different supported languages on different function namespace managers, they can extend for their own FSM. If that's the case, we cannot even predict what user wants at this point. Maybe user wants a blacklist instead of a whitelist. Maybe they want a regex? Who knows?
Also, throw Exception if we're creating or executing functions with unsupported language, and I think it would creating a new error code to formalize this error path?
timeline.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: The function namespace manager needs to configure which language it supports, together with how to invoke that type of functions. The execution of a function is in function namespace manager, so why the configuration should live in the engine? Just like if a specific function namespace manager manages a catalog.schema, so you would call that function namespace manager's createFunction when you create the function, you would call that function namespace manager's executeFunction when you invoke it. The function namespace manager also needs to configure the remote tier and protocol used to execute the function. I can't see why these logic should fit in the engine. You can have function namespace manager A which can support language L1, and L2, where for L1 it will execute the function in T1 and for L2 in T2, while having another function namespace manager supporting language L1 and L3 that runs them in T1' and T3. It's way easier to manage these in function namespace manager than in engine. Remote function is not something that will be able to work out of the box. You HAVE to setup a remote function server to run the functions. The function you introduce has tighter relationship to the UDF server and function metadata than to Presto engine.
replies.author: rongrong
